articles.headline: At Czech Spa Town, ‘Russia for Us Is the Past, and It Was Not Pleasant’
articles.snippet: Since the 18th century, Russians have flocked to the healing waters of Karlovy Vary. Now, the Czech government has barred them from visiting the country, and the town must reinvent itself.
articles.abstract: Since the 18th century, Russians have flocked to the healing waters of Karlovy Vary. Now, the Czech government has barred them from visiting the country, and the town must reinvent itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: James Bond, poisoned by a villain in the film “Casino Royale,” almost died in the forecourt of the Grandhotel Pupp, a majestic reinvention of what, under Communism, was called the Grand Hotel Moskva, a shabby lodge popular with members of the Czech and Soviet nomenklatura.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: ‘We Are in Trauma’: Memphis Reels From the Latest of Many Blows
articles.snippet: Tyre Nichols’s fatal beating took its place on a roster of traumatic events that have helped shape the story of Memphis as much as its world-famous musical innovations.
articles.abstract: Tyre Nichols’s fatal beating took its place on a roster of traumatic events that have helped shape the story of Memphis as much as its world-famous musical innovations.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Jury Rules for Elon Musk and Tesla in Investor Lawsuit Over Tweets
articles.snippet: The case centered on whether investors lost money because they believed Mr. Musk’s social media posts about taking Tesla private in 2018.
articles.abstract: The case centered on whether investors lost money because they believed Mr. Musk’s social media posts about taking Tesla private in 2018.
articles.lead_paragraph: A jury decided Friday that Elon Musk was not liable for losses suffered by investors after he posted messages on Twitter saying he had secured the funding to take Tesla private in 2018.
articles.byline: By Kalley Huang and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Gautam Adani’s Rise Was Intertwined With India’s. Now It’s Unraveling.
articles.snippet: The tycoon often said the Adani Group’s goals were in lock step with India’s needs. Now, the company’s fortunes are crashing, a collapse whose pain will be felt across the country.
articles.abstract: The tycoon often said the Adani Group’s goals were in lock step with India’s needs. Now, the company’s fortunes are crashing, a collapse whose pain will be felt across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gautam Adani began the year as one of the richest men who ever lived, an upstart billionaire whose conglomerate, one of India’s largest, had surged in value by 2,500 percent in five years.
articles.byline: By Alex Travelli

articles.headline: Democrats Overhaul Party’s Primary Calendar, Upending a Political Tradition
articles.snippet: The proposal radically reshapes the way the party picks its presidential nominees, putting more racially diverse states at the front of the line.
articles.abstract: The proposal radically reshapes the way the party picks its presidential nominees, putting more racially diverse states at the front of the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Upending decades of political tradition, the Democratic National Committee on Saturday approved a sweeping overhaul of the Democratic primary process, a critical step in President Biden’s effort to transform the way the party picks its presidential nominees.
articles.byline: By Katie Glueck

articles.headline: The Pentagon Saw a Warship Boondoggle. Congress Saw Jobs.
articles.snippet: After years of crippling problems and a changing mission, the Navy pushed to retire nine of its newest ships. Then the lobbying started.
articles.abstract: After years of crippling problems and a changing mission, the Navy pushed to retire nine of its newest ships. Then the lobbying started.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The 387-foot-long warships tied up at the Jacksonville Navy base were acclaimed as some of the most modern in the United States fleet: nimble, superfast vessels designed to operate in coastal waters and hunt down enemy submarines, destroy anti-ship mines and repel attacks from small boats, like those often operated by Iran.

articles.headline: Muscle Cars, Balaclavas and Fists: How the Scorpions Rolled Through Memphis
articles.snippet: Residents say the street crime unit was an intimidating and sometimes violent presence in the city. Five Scorpion officers are charged with murdering Tyre Nichols during an arrest.
articles.abstract: Residents say the street crime unit was an intimidating and sometimes violent presence in the city. Five Scorpion officers are charged with murdering Tyre Nichols during an arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 14 months, officers from the high-profile Scorpion unit of the Memphis Police Department patrolled city streets with an air of menace, zooming up on targets, jumping out of their Dodge Chargers at a dead run, shouting at people to get out of their vehicles, lie down on the ground.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Matthew Rosenberg, Joseph Goldstein, Mike Baker, Kassie Bracken and Mark Walker

articles.headline: Look! Up in the Sky! It’s a … Chinese Spy Balloon?
articles.snippet: How the balloon went from a local sky oddity to an international diplomatic disrupter to “a shriveled Kleenex.”
articles.abstract: How the balloon went from a local sky oddity to an international diplomatic disrupter to “a shriveled Kleenex.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As far as spy thrillers go, this one unfolded pretty slowly: A giant Chinese spy balloon air-dawdled its way toward the Eastern Seaboard for several days until it was blown out of the sky on Saturday by the U.S. military.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers

articles.headline: FTX Inquiry Expands as Prosecutors Reach Out to Former Executives
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are speaking with lawyers for former officials at the collapsed crypto exchange FTX and scrutinizing the immediate family of its founder, Sam Bankman-Fried.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are speaking with lawyers for former officials at the collapsed crypto exchange FTX and scrutinizing the immediate family of its founder, Sam Bankman-Fried.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are scrutinizing a growing array of people tied to Sam Bankman-Fried’s collapsed cryptocurrency empire, including his father, his brother and former colleagues, as part of a rapidly expanding investigation into one of the biggest American financial crime cases in more than a decade, according to 13 people with knowledge of the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Downing of Chinese Spy Balloon Ends Chapter in a Diplomatic Crisis
articles.snippet: The balloon, spotted earlier this week over the western United States, was brought down when an F-22 fighter jet fired an air-to-air missile at it off the coast of South Carolina.
articles.abstract: The balloon, spotted earlier this week over the western United States, was brought down when an F-22 fighter jet fired an air-to-air missile at it off the coast of South Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States shot down a Chinese spy balloon on Saturday that had spent the last week traversing the country, an explosive end to a drama that put a diplomatic crisis between the world’s two great powers onto television screens in real time.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Pervez Musharraf, Former Military Ruler of Pakistan, Dies at 79
articles.snippet: Mr. Musharraf took power in a bloodless coup in late 1999 but resigned under threat of impeachment in 2008. He drew fire for his ties to Washington.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musharraf took power in a bloodless coup in late 1999 but resigned under threat of impeachment in 2008. He drew fire for his ties to Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pervez Musharraf, the onetime military ruler of a nuclear-armed Pakistan who promised critical support for Washington’s campaign against Al Qaeda after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but faced growing resistance at home in a land seething with anti-Western passions, died on Sunday in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. He was 79.
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Stephen Kinzer

articles.headline: In West Bank, Settlers Sense Their Moment After Far Right’s Rise
articles.snippet: After a surge in violence, there are fears of a wider escalation in the occupied West Bank. Israeli settlers see an opportunity, and Palestinians fear what’s next.
articles.abstract: After a surge in violence, there are fears of a wider escalation in the occupied West Bank. Israeli settlers see an opportunity, and Palestinians fear what’s next.
articles.lead_paragraph: The remains of Or Haim, an illegal settlement outpost, lie strewn across a windswept hilltop in the north of the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Two dozen Israeli settlers erected a few flimsy huts there one night last month, and by morning, the Israeli Army had demolished them.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim

articles.headline: The Blurred Lines Between Goldman C.E.O.’s Day Job and His D.J. Gig
articles.snippet: David Solomon brushes off D.J.ing as a minor hobby that has little to do with his work at the bank, but his activities may pose potential conflicts of interest.
articles.abstract: David Solomon brushes off D.J.ing as a minor hobby that has little to do with his work at the bank, but his activities may pose potential conflicts of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Katherine Rosman

articles.headline: Flowers, Fresh Fish and Movies: China Is Spending Again, Cautiously
articles.snippet: The outlook for the world’s second-largest economy is brighter as consumer spending picked up after “zero Covid” was lifted. But scars remain from the harsh pandemic restrictions.
articles.abstract: The outlook for the world’s second-largest economy is brighter as consumer spending picked up after “zero Covid” was lifted. But scars remain from the harsh pandemic restrictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: In downtown Nanjing, China, a fishmonger sold a lot more ribbon fish than usual for Lunar New Year family gatherings two weeks ago. A florist in a run-down shopping mall on the south side of the city sold more roses.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Taking Aim at Trump, Koch Network Will Back G.O.P. Primary Candidates
articles.snippet: The move by the alliance of conservative donors could provide an enormous boost to a Republican alternative to the former president.
articles.abstract: The move by the alliance of conservative donors could provide an enormous boost to a Republican alternative to the former president.
articles.lead_paragraph: The donor network created by the billionaire industrialist brothers Charles G. and David H. Koch is preparing to get involved in the presidential primaries in 2024, with the aim of turning “the page on the past” in a thinly veiled rebuke of former President Donald J. Trump, according to an internal memo.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: U.S. Navy Divers Work to Recover Debris From Chinese Spy Balloon as Diplomacy Dwindles
articles.snippet: The effort off the coast of South Carolina is expected to take days, and Navy and Coast Guard ships have been sent to the scene. U.S. officials are watching for retaliation from China.
articles.abstract: The effort off the coast of South Carolina is expected to take days, and Navy and Coast Guard ships have been sent to the scene. U.S. officials are watching for retaliation from China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Navy divers were searching for debris from the Chinese spy balloon that a U.S. fighter jet shot down off the coast of South Carolina, defense officials said on Sunday, as the fallout from the dramatic confrontation between the world’s two great powers showed no signs of easing.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Balloon Incident Reveals More Than Spying as Competition With China Intensifies
articles.snippet: There is nothing new about superpowers spying on one another, even from balloons. But for pure gall, there was something different this time.
articles.abstract: There is nothing new about superpowers spying on one another, even from balloons. But for pure gall, there was something different this time.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be months before American intelligence agencies can compare the audacious flight of a Chinese surveillance balloon across the country to other intrusions on America’s national security systems, to determine how it ranks.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Kamala Harris Is Trying to Define Her Vice Presidency. Even Her Allies Are Tired of Waiting.
articles.snippet: Ms. Harris is struggling to carve out a lane for herself in what may be one of the most consequential periods in the vice presidency.
articles.abstract: Ms. Harris is struggling to carve out a lane for herself in what may be one of the most consequential periods in the vice presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kamala Harris was frustrated. The text of a speech she had been given to deliver in Chicago to the nation’s biggest teachers’ union was just another dreary, scripted talk that said little of any consequence.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Katie Rogers and Peter Baker

articles.headline: At This School, Computer Science Class Now Includes Critiquing Chatbots
articles.snippet: Move over, coding. Some schools are asking student programmers to think critically about rapid advances in artificial intelligence.
articles.abstract: Move over, coding. Some schools are asking student programmers to think critically about rapid advances in artificial intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marisa Shuman’s computer science class at the Young Women’s Leadership School of the Bronx began as usual on a recent January morning.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Disney’s Iger Returns to Familiar Stage, but With Different Challenges
articles.snippet: The company reports quarterly earnings on Wednesday, and Wall Street is expecting it to lay out a new streaming strategy and operating structure.
articles.abstract: The company reports quarterly earnings on Wednesday, and Wall Street is expecting it to lay out a new streaming strategy and operating structure.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to reporting quarterly earnings, Robert A. Iger is an old pro. He has done it 58 times as Disney’s chief executive. But the next one, scheduled for Wednesday, will require him to give a performance for the corporate ages.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Musk Pledged to Cleanse Twitter of Child Abuse Content. It’s Been Rough Going.
articles.snippet: Child sexual abuse imagery spreads on Twitter even after the company is notified: One video drew 120,000 views. “Sewer rats,” as one regulator described bad actors, remain.
articles.abstract: Child sexual abuse imagery spreads on Twitter even after the company is notified: One video drew 120,000 views. “Sewer rats,” as one regulator described bad actors, remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over 120,000 views of a video showing a boy being sexually assaulted. A recommendation engine suggesting that a user follow content related to exploited children. Users continually posting abusive material, delays in taking it down when it is detected and friction with organizations that police it.
articles.byline: By Michael H. Keller and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Tesla’s Pickup Truck Is Coming Soon. Maybe.
articles.snippet: Already two years behind schedule, the Cybertruck has experts wondering how the company will manufacture its unusual stainless steel “exoskeleton.”
articles.abstract: Already two years behind schedule, the Cybertruck has experts wondering how the company will manufacture its unusual stainless steel “exoskeleton.”
articles.lead_paragraph: More than three years after Elon Musk stunned the auto industry with an electric pickup truck that looked more like a stealth fighter than a way to haul two-by-fours and drywall, Tesla said last month that it would begin building the vehicle by the end of 2023.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: China’s Balloon Dispute Aims Attention at Xi’s Leadership
articles.snippet: The flap with the United States raises concerns about how China wields its power in a climate where one wrong move could set off an accidental conflict.
articles.abstract: The flap with the United States raises concerns about how China wields its power in a climate where one wrong move could set off an accidental conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese balloon that bumbled its way across the United States has launched a thousand questions about its real intent.
articles.byline: By David Pierson

articles.headline: Many on Wall St. Turned Down Carlyle Before It Hired Its C.E.O.
articles.snippet: Harvey Schwartz, who was once in the running for the top job at Goldman Sachs, is taking over at the investing giant after the abrupt exit of its former C.E.O.
articles.abstract: Harvey Schwartz, who was once in the running for the top job at Goldman Sachs, is taking over at the investing giant after the abrupt exit of its former C.E.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: In November, Bill Conway, then interim chief executive of Carlyle, the investing behemoth he helped to start in 1987, walked around the firm’s Manhattan headquarters asking younger employees: “Would you like to take my job?”
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell, Rob Copeland and Kate Kelly
